head.title: Officials Quell An Uprising At a Prison In Indiana

hedline.hl1: Officials Quell An Uprising At a Prison In Indiana
hedline.hl2: Officials Quell an Uprising at a Prison in Indiana

abstract.p: Male inmates at medium-security state prison in New Castle, Ind, riot, injuring two guards and several inmates before being quelled; officers are locked in bathrooms before being released by inmates at New Castle Correctional Facility; about 500 of prison's 1,668 inmates are involved (M)

block.p: Inmates at a medium-security state prison here rioted Tuesday, injuring two guards and several inmates.

Officers employed by the G.E.O. Group of Boca Raton, Fla., which runs the prison, were locked in bathrooms before being released by inmates at New Castle Correctional Facility, a men's prison about 40 miles east of Indianapolis.
Officials said the riot began after a group of prisoners took off their shirts in the recreation area to show staff that they would not comply with orders to keep them on.
Inmates at a medium-security state prison here rioted Tuesday, injuring two guards and several inmates.

Officers employed by the G.E.O. Group of Boca Raton, Fla., which runs the prison, were locked in bathrooms before being released by inmates at New Castle Correctional Facility, a men's prison about 40 miles east of Indianapolis.

The fighting began at 2 p.m. and was contained by 4:30 p.m., but some inmates were not back in their cells as of 7 p.m., when guards used percussion grenades to subdue some inmates who were still in a common area, said J. David Donahue, the Indiana correction commissioner.
The inmates in the courtyard were in handcuffs and were being processed back into their cells, Mr. Donahue said. One of the guards remained hospitalized. The other injuries were not serious.
Officials said that about 500 of the prison's 1,668 inmates were involved.

The officials said the riot began after a group of prisoners who had been transferred from Arizona took off their shirts in the recreation area to show staff that they would not comply with orders to keep them on.

''It went from recreation to a riot in a minute,'' said a 21-year-old corrections officer who insisted on anonymity for fear of not getting a new job after quitting on Tuesday. She said she had hidden in a bathroom before being escorted out of the inner yard by inmates at about 4 p.m.

The Arizona inmates, who began being housed here in January, crossed from their section of the facility into the Indiana inmates' section and attacked prison guards, she said. Inmates commandeered radios and key controls that open doors and fences but never broke through the outer fence. Fires were set in the courtyard.
''The point is, the system worked,'' said Kit Crane, the Henry County prosecutor. ''No one got through to the outside of the facility.''
